title: 105_s896
content: The "Landmine Elimination Act of 1997" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Congress found that a ban on anti-personnel landmines was supported by senior military officers and would not compromise military effectiveness. They noted the significant casualties caused by landmines in Vietnam and Bosnia. Soldiers under NATO command have been injured and 9 killed by landmines. The Department of State estimates that someone is killed or injured by a landmine every 22 minutes. President Clinton declared the US would aggressively pursue an international agreement to ban anti-personnel landmines. Various organizations declared goals for landmine-free zones. The UN General Assembly passed a resolution to pursue a ban on landmines. The United States is pushing for a treaty to ban anti-personnel landmines, with formal negotiations set to begin in Oslo, Norway in September 1997. The US aims to use its international influence to secure broad support for the treaty, which would enhance security and humanitarian interests by deterring the use of landmines against US Armed Forces and civilians. The US aims to secure broad support for the treaty to enhance security and humanitarian interests by deterring the use of landmines against US Armed Forces and civilians. SEC. 3. RESTRICTION ON NEW DEPLOYMENTS OF ANTI-PERSONNEL LANDMINES. Beginning on January 1, 2000, no funds may be used for new deployments of anti-personnel landmines. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress within 180 days outlining alternatives for such deployments on the Korean Peninsula. The President can delay the restriction if new deployments are deemed essential for the defense of South Korea during a war or emergency. The report under subsection (d) must describe efforts to implement proposals from previous reports by the Secretary of Defense and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "anti-personnel landmine" refers to munitions designed to detonate by person contact, excluding command-detonated Claymore munitions. "New deployments of anti-personnel landmines" are those placed after January 1, 2000.
